articles.headline: Leon Black Agreed to Pay $62.5 Million to Settle Epstein-Related Claims
articles.snippet: The private equity mogul struck a deal with the U.S. Virgin Islands to avoid a potential lawsuit over his ties to Jeffrey Epstein.
articles.abstract: The private equity mogul struck a deal with the U.S. Virgin Islands to avoid a potential lawsuit over his ties to Jeffrey Epstein.
articles.lead_paragraph: The billionaire investor Leon Black agreed to pay $62.5 million to the U.S. Virgin Islands in January to be released from any potential claims arising out of the territory’s three-year investigation into the sex trafficking operation of the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein, according to a copy of the settlement agreement.

articles.headline: In Black Sea Showdown, Russia Batters Ukraine’s Ability to Export Grain
articles.snippet: Russia held exercises demonstrating its power to sink ships and stop those that try to run its blockade. For Ukrainian food exports to resume, Moscow said, a list of demands must be met.
articles.abstract: Russia held exercises demonstrating its power to sink ships and stop those that try to run its blockade. For Ukrainian food exports to resume, Moscow said, a list of demands must be met.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russia barraged Ukrainian ports for the fourth night in a row on Friday, striking granaries in Odesa and mounting a show of naval force on the Black Sea in a deepening showdown that imperils a vital part of the global food supply.
articles.byline: By Ivan Nechepurenko, Farnaz Fassihi, Victoria Kim and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: An Untested Judge in the Trump Documents Case
articles.snippet: Judge Aileen M. Cannon’s ruling to start the Trump documents trial in May 2024 showed, for now, that she is the jurist defenders have described: level-headed and not beholden to the man who appointed her.
articles.abstract: Judge Aileen M. Cannon’s ruling to start the Trump documents trial in May 2024 showed, for now, that she is the jurist defenders have described: level-headed and not beholden to the man who appointed her.
articles.lead_paragraph: Judge Aileen M. Cannon, a previously obscure Trump judicial appointee, has been viewed with incredulity by much of the legal establishment ever since she issued a ruling temporarily halting the federal investigation into the former president’s handling of classified documents. After a conservative appeals court slapped her down, Democrats said she was either incompetent or some kind of black-robed Trojan horse for the MAGA movement.

articles.headline: Beijing Offers Love, but Chinese Entrepreneurs Aren’t Buying It
articles.snippet: The government’s new 31-point guidelines meant to inspire confidence feel empty to businesspeople after a three-year clampdown and no concrete changes.
articles.abstract: The government’s new 31-point guidelines meant to inspire confidence feel empty to businesspeople after a three-year clampdown and no concrete changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the darkest moments of the financial crisis in 2008, former Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao lectured a group of U.S. government officials and business executives in New York. “In the face of economic difficulties,” he said, “confidence is more precious than gold.”

articles.headline: UPS Contract Talks Go Down to the Wire as a Possible Strike Looms
articles.snippet: With the Teamsters contract set to expire Aug. 1, pay for part-time workers is a major hurdle. A walkout could rattle the U.S. economy.
articles.abstract: With the Teamsters contract set to expire Aug. 1, pay for part-time workers is a major hurdle. A walkout could rattle the U.S. economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barely a week before the contract for more than 325,000 United Parcel Service workers expires, union and company negotiators have yet to reach an agreement to avert a strike that could knock the American economy off stride.

articles.headline: How a Drugmaker Profited by Slow-Walking a Promising H.I.V. Therapy
articles.snippet: Gilead delayed a new version of a drug, allowing it to extend the patent life of a blockbuster line of medications, internal documents show.
articles.abstract: Gilead delayed a new version of a drug, allowing it to extend the patent life of a blockbuster line of medications, internal documents show.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2004, Gilead Sciences decided to stop pursuing a new H.I.V. drug. The public explanation was that it wasn’t sufficiently different from an existing treatment to warrant further development.
articles.byline: By Rebecca Robbins and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: How Do the White House’s A.I. Commitments Stack Up?
articles.snippet: Seven leading A.I. companies made eight promises about what they’ll do with their technology. Our columnist sizes up their potential impact.
articles.abstract: Seven leading A.I. companies made eight promises about what they’ll do with their technology. Our columnist sizes up their potential impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, the White House announced that it had secured “voluntary commitments” from seven leading A.I. companies to manage the risks posed by artificial intelligence.

articles.headline: In Belarus, the Protests Were Three Years Ago. The Crackdown Is Never-Ending.
articles.snippet: Aleksandr G. Lukashenko brutally repressed those who opposed his claim of re-election as president. The crackdown on dissent has only deepened since.
articles.abstract: Aleksandr G. Lukashenko brutally repressed those who opposed his claim of re-election as president. The crackdown on dissent has only deepened since.
articles.lead_paragraph: The recent high school graduate selected her wardrobe carefully as she headed off to a summer folk festival.
articles.byline: By Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

articles.headline: A Decade Ago, Jeff Bezos Bought a Newspaper. Now He’s Paying Attention to It Again.
articles.snippet: The Amazon founder, who purchased The Washington Post for $250 million in 2013, has taken a more active role in the paper’s operations this year.
articles.abstract: The Amazon founder, who purchased The Washington Post for $250 million in 2013, has taken a more active role in the paper’s operations this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: During his tenure as executive editor at The Washington Post, Martin Baron ran into a persistent problem.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson

articles.headline: Student Loans Come Due Again: Many Borrowers Will Lose a Lifeline
articles.snippet: The payment pause freed up money that gave people breathing room — or allowed them to help family members in need. They will soon have to budget for that expense.
articles.abstract: The payment pause freed up money that gave people breathing room — or allowed them to help family members in need. They will soon have to budget for that expense.
articles.lead_paragraph: With her student loan payments on hold for three years, Ashley Dorn, a public school music teacher, found another use for the money she saved during the moratorium. She used the extra cash to pay off $10,000 in credit card debt, a bill that had been nagging at her for a decade.

articles.headline: Venezuela’s Oil Industry Is Broken. Now It’s Breaking the Environment.
articles.snippet: Gas flares and leaking pipelines from Venezuela’s once-booming oil industry, hobbled by U.S. sanctions and mismanagement, are polluting towns and a major lake.
articles.abstract: Gas flares and leaking pipelines from Venezuela’s once-booming oil industry, hobbled by U.S. sanctions and mismanagement, are polluting towns and a major lake.
articles.lead_paragraph: Each morning, José Aguilera inspects the leaves of his banana and coffee plants on his farm in eastern Venezuela and calculates how much he can harvest — almost nothing.
articles.byline: By Isayen Herrera, Sheyla Urdaneta and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez

articles.headline: The Steep Cost of Ron DeSantis’s Vaccine Turnabout
articles.snippet: Once a vaccine advocate, the Florida governor lost his enthusiasm for the shot before the Delta wave sent Covid hospitalizations and deaths soaring. It’s a grim chapter he now leaves out of his rosy retelling of his pandemic response.
articles.abstract: Once a vaccine advocate, the Florida governor lost his enthusiasm for the shot before the Delta wave sent Covid hospitalizations and deaths soaring. It’s a grim chapter he now leaves out of his rosy retelling of his pandemic response.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a Saturday in September 2020, with Covid-19 killing more than 600 Americans daily and hundreds of thousands of deaths still to come, Dr. Deborah L. Birx, a member of the White House coronavirus task force, heard her cellphone ring. It was Dr. Scott Rivkees, the Florida surgeon general. He was distraught.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, Patricia Mazzei and Albert Sun

articles.headline: Far Right May Rise as Kingmaker in Spanish Election
articles.snippet: A messier political landscape has lent leverage to the extremes, leaving a hard-right party with a chance to share power for the first time since Franco.
articles.abstract: A messier political landscape has lent leverage to the extremes, leaving a hard-right party with a chance to share power for the first time since Franco.
articles.lead_paragraph: If Spain’s national elections on Sunday turn out as most polls and analysts suggest, mainstream conservatives may come out on top but need allies on the political fringe to govern, ushering the first hard-right party into power since the Franco dictatorship.

articles.headline: Drugmakers Are ‘Throwing the Kitchen Sink’ to Halt Medicare Price Negotiations
articles.snippet: The government will soon announce the first 10 medications that will be subject to price negotiations with Medicare under a new law. Drugmakers are fighting the measure in court.
articles.abstract: The government will soon announce the first 10 medications that will be subject to price negotiations with Medicare under a new law. Drugmakers are fighting the measure in court.
articles.lead_paragraph: The pharmaceutical industry, which suffered a stinging defeat last year when President Biden signed a law authorizing Medicare to negotiate the price of some prescription medicines, is now waging a broad-based assault on the measure — just as the negotiations are about to begin.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Rebecca Robbins

articles.headline: How a Mexican Lager Quietly Rose to Become America’s Best-Selling Beer
articles.snippet: A decade before Bud Light faced a conservative-led boycott over a transgender influencer, Modelo Especial was on track to take the No. 1 spot.
articles.abstract: A decade before Bud Light faced a conservative-led boycott over a transgender influencer, Modelo Especial was on track to take the No. 1 spot.
articles.lead_paragraph: More beers in America are being paired with lime than ever before.

articles.headline: Israel’s Identity Hangs in Balance Ahead of Key Vote on New Law
articles.snippet: Lawmakers are set to vote Monday on whether to limit the Supreme Court’s power as one element of a government plan to overhaul judicial authority. It is part of a profound rift over Israel’s nature and future.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers are set to vote Monday on whether to limit the Supreme Court’s power as one element of a government plan to overhaul judicial authority. It is part of a profound rift over Israel’s nature and future.
articles.lead_paragraph: When tens of thousands of Israelis marched up to Jerusalem this weekend to protest the far-right government’s plan to limit judicial power, many were driven by an urgent fear that the government is trying to steal the country that their parents and grandparents fought to build against the odds.

articles.headline: U.S. Confronts Tight but Turbulent Relationship With Israel
articles.snippet: President Biden has cautioned Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu against pursuing a proposal to rein in Israel’s judiciary, a plan that has deeply divided Israeli society.
articles.abstract: President Biden has cautioned Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu against pursuing a proposal to rein in Israel’s judiciary, a plan that has deeply divided Israeli society.
articles.lead_paragraph: Long before moving into the White House, President Biden compared the relationship between the United States and Israel to that of close friends. “We love one another,” he said, “and we drive one another crazy.”
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: As Inquiries Compound, Justice System Pours Resources Into Scrutinizing Trump
articles.snippet: For all their complexity, the Trump-related prosecutions have not significantly constrained the ability of prosecutors to carry out their regular duties, officials have said.
articles.abstract: For all their complexity, the Trump-related prosecutions have not significantly constrained the ability of prosecutors to carry out their regular duties, officials have said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jack Smith, the special counsel overseeing criminal investigations into former President Donald J. Trump, employs 40 to 60 career prosecutors, paralegals and support staff, augmented by a rotating cast of F.B.I. agents and technical specialists, according to people familiar with the situation.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush, Ben Protess, Alan Feuer and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Hollywood Strikes Mean Steady Diet of Reruns, Game Shows and Reality TV
articles.snippet: TV viewers across the U.S. will see fewer new scripted shows, a trend that could continue well into next year if the walkouts continue.
articles.abstract: TV viewers across the U.S. will see fewer new scripted shows, a trend that could continue well into next year if the walkouts continue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Scripted television series premiering at a slower pace. The “New Releases” and “Just Added” banners on streaming services piling up with reality shows, documentaries and international fare. Ninety-minute episodes of “Survivor” and “60 Minutes.” A steady diet of Pat Sajak, Steve Harvey and David Spade hosting game shows in prime time.

articles.headline: Seeking Full Honors, Some Ukrainian Families Wait to Bury Their Dead
articles.snippet: Thousands of families have buried soldiers in cemeteries across Ukraine in “Alleys of Heroes.” But some have held off, awaiting a version of Arlington National Cemetery.
articles.abstract: Thousands of families have buried soldiers in cemeteries across Ukraine in “Alleys of Heroes.” But some have held off, awaiting a version of Arlington National Cemetery.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dmytro Gubariev’s remains have been sitting in his bedroom for 10 months, unmoved. That’s how long his mother has been waiting to bury his ashes.

articles.headline: A Flood of New Workers Has Made the Fed’s Job Less Painful. Can It Persist?
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve officials thought job gains would taper off more, but they’ve remained strong. An improving supply of workers has been crucial.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve officials thought job gains would taper off more, but they’ve remained strong. An improving supply of workers has been crucial.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hotels in New York’s Adirondack Mountains are having an easier time hiring this summer, partly as immigrants enter the country in greater numbers and provide a steady supply of seasonal help that was hard to come by in and just after the pandemic.

articles.headline: Thorny Rules and Maybe an Absent Trump: A Month Out From the First G.O.P. Debate
articles.snippet: Republican presidential candidates are supposed to face off in Milwaukee on Aug. 23. But Donald Trump, the field’s front-runner, may not show up, and others have yet to make the cut.
articles.abstract: Republican presidential candidates are supposed to face off in Milwaukee on Aug. 23. But Donald Trump, the field’s front-runner, may not show up, and others have yet to make the cut.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a month to go before the first Republican presidential debate, the stage in Milwaukee remains remarkably unsettled, with the front-runner, former President Donald J. Trump, waffling on his attendance and the rest of the participants far from certain.
